images.copyright: Trumpeter swans at Kelly Warm Springs, near Kelly, Wyoming (© DEEPOL by plainpicture)
images.title: Did they forget to migrate this winter?
images.caption: Did they forget to migrate this winter?
images.desc: Native to North America, trumpeter swans live near rivers, lakes, and coastal byways in most parts of the United States and Canada. Depending on where they live, these swans are either resident birds or medium-range migrators. What they all require, though, is open water during winter, since their diet consists almost entirely of aquatic plants. That may be why the swans in this image are drawn to the waters of Kelly Warm Springs in Wyoming (mountain region, Western United States), which won't freeze even as snow lines the banks.

images.copyright: Skating on a frozen canal near the windmills at Kinderdijk in the Netherlands (© Lourens Smak/Alamy)
images.title: 'Winterpret' on ice
images.caption: 'Winterpret' on ice
images.desc: These skaters in the village of Kinderdijk are embracing 'winterpret,' a Dutch word that means 'winter joy' or 'winter fun.' Whenever temperatures drop low enough, many locals take to the ice and skate away on a complex network of canals. These waterways were built centuries ago—along with pumps, dykes, and the windmills pictured here—to protect the village of Kinderdijk by diverting water from the land. It's an important job, since Kinderdijk, like much of the Netherlands, lies below sea level and flooding is a major problem. Nowadays a modern water management system with multiple pumping stations does the work, and the windmills are left with a new job–to maintain an iconic Dutch scene. In 1997, the Kinderdijk windmills were designated as a UNESCO World Heritage site.

images.copyright: The Church of St. Thomas above the village of Praprotno, for Slovenia Independence and Unity Day (© Guy Edwardes/Minden Pictures)
images.title: It's Slovenia's Independence and Unity Day
images.caption: It's Slovenia's Independence and Unity Day
images.desc: Today we're featuring an image of the Slovenian village of Praprotno and its Church of St. Thomas for the country's Independence and Unity Day. On December 26, 1990 the results of a Slovenian vote on the country's independence were announced. More than 95 percent of voters answered 'Yes' to the question: Should the Republic of Slovenia become an independent and sovereign state?

images.copyright: Sand sculpture of Santa Claus at Puri, Odisha (© Getty Images)
images.title: An artistic way to observe festivals
images.caption: An artistic way to observe festivals
images.desc: What you see in today’s homepage image is a sand sculpture created by noted artist Sudarshan Pattnaik, on Christmas day back in 2008. Pattnaik is recognised throughout the world as a sand artist, and has represented India in numerous exhibitions and competitions, most recently the 2019 Revere Beach International Sand Sculpting Festival in Boston, USA. Hailing from Puri, Odisha where he still lives, Sudarshan Pattnaik was awarded (among his many other achievements) the Padma Shri award by the government, in 2014.

images.copyright: A herd of reindeer in Norway (© Lena Granefelt/plainpicture)
images.title: Dashing through the snow
images.caption: Dashing through the snow
images.desc: While many associate reindeer with the wonder of the Christmas holidays, these animals are magical in their own way. Known in North America as caribou, reindeer are well-adapted to live in cold, rugged Arctic regions. They're built to withstand frigid temperatures with the help of thick, dense fur and noses that warm the air before they breathe it in.

images.copyright: Orchha Palace on a misty morning at sunrise (© Luigi Vaccarella/Sime/eStock Photo)
images.title: The Orchha palace on a misty morning
images.caption: The Orchha palace on a misty morning
images.desc: Sunrise can be quite a pleasant sight on a misty morning at Orchha Palace, Madhya Pradesh. Of course, we advise you to dress warm if you visit in the winter. Most probably, you’d experience below 10-degree temperatures in the morning around this time of the year. Alternatively, you could just sit back and enjoy the view on today’s homepage!

images.copyright: The Seventeen-Arch Bridge over Kunming Lake in Beijing Summer Palace, China (© Jia Wang/Getty Images)
images.title: Seventeen arches at sunset
images.caption: Seventeen arches at sunset
images.desc: When it's winter solstice time (shortest day and longest night of the year) in the Northern Hemisphere, the setting sun shines under the Seventeen-Arch Bridge of the Summer Palace in Beijing, causing this romantic glow. In the 18th century, during the reign of the Qing dynasty of China, Emperor Qinglong ordered the construction of this 1.8 square kilometre collection of gardens, lakes, and various structures including temples and small palaces. It's one of Beijing's premier attractions and will be crowded today with visitors headed to the bridge in time for sunset.

tooltips.walls: ಈ ಇಮೇಜ್ ಡೌನ್‌ಲೋಡ್ ಮಾಡಿ. ಈ ಇಮೇಜ್‌ನ ಬಳಕೆ ಕೇವಲ ವಾಲ್‌ಪೇಪರ್‌ಗೆ ನಿರ್ಬಂಧಿತವಾಗಿದೆ.
